bugs.cf_release_notes:
Cause: Authorization fails to connect and access the Guvnor repository in BRMS with JBDS 6.

Consequence: Login fails to sync with the Guvnor repository.

Fix: BRMS / BPMS 6.0, no longer uses this Guvnor plugin, but rather uses the existing Git tooling like EGit to do the integration.

Result: Authorization is not required to sync with the GIT repository as it now replaces the Guvnor repository.
bugs.summary: JBDS 6 with BRMS tooling fails to authorize for Guvnor repo access

bugs.creator: Marek Winkler
bugs.cf_release_notes:
Cause: The KIE module injection through CDI does not work in container as the Drools resource loading mechanism differs with the JBoss EAP application server environment which now uses the JBoss VFS.

Consequence: Drools was unable to locate the KieModule on the classpath as the pom.properties file resides in a directory which is named according to the maven artifact and the standard java resource loading mechanism failed to
locate it.

Fix: This issue has been resolved and the application defines a CDI bean which is able to inject a KieSession defined in kmodule.xml.

Result: CDI injection of Drools KieBase and KieSession with EAP is now working.
bugs.summary: KIE module injection through CDI does not work in container

bugs.cf_release_notes:
Summary: While using Google Chrome, the Guided Editor overflows window width and prevents the user from being able to view the right-side buttons for adding, moving, and deleting LHS and RHS elements.

Cause: While opening an existing .gre.drl or .gre.dslr rule in the Guided Editor, the Chrome browser hides the right-side buttons for LHS and RHS elements. When creating a new .gre.drl or .gre.dslr rule, the green plus buttons are visible within the visible window in Google Chrome; however, adding any LHS (WHEN) or RHS (THEN) element will move the green plus buttons outside of the visible window.

Consequence: The overflowed window width in the Google Chrome browser encumbers the user from being able to select the LHS and RHS element buttons.

Workaround: A current workaround is to open Guided Editor with a Firefox browser while working with .gre.drl or .gre.dslr rules.

Result: Using the Firefox browser allows the user to select the right-side buttons for adding, moving, and deleting LHS and RHS elements.
bugs.cf_environment:
Google Chrome 27 @ Fedora 17,
Safari 5.1.3 @ Mac OS 10.7.3
bugs.summary: Guided Editor overflows window width in Google Chrome

bugs.cf_release_notes:
Summary:  While using the Guided Editor, users who re-open a file have issues with the constraint operator list box. That is, saved data is reverted to “- - - please choose - - -” and the drop-down box only displays four options: equal to, not equal to, is null, and is not null. 

Cause: Create a GRE rule and add a condition with a value constraint such as greater than, less than, less than or equal to, greater than or equal to, matches, or sounds like. Save the file and re-open it. Note, if the value constraint is equals to, not equals to, is null, or is not null, the constraints come back unchanged; however, the other options are significantly reduced if the value constraints need to be changed.

Consequence: Once the file is opened after an initial save, the conditional value constraint reverts to “- - -  please choose - - -” instead of its previous constraint. In most cases, an alert of “Are you sure you want to discard unsaved data?” will appear after saving the initial changes. This may be an indication that the value constraints will become corrupt and revert to “- - - please choose - - -.”

Workaround: There is no current workaround to this issue.

Result: The conditional value constraints are reverted to “- - - please choose - - -” or the options are significantly reduced based on the initial conditional value constraint choice.
bugs.summary: GRE constraint operator list box problems when re-opening file

bugs.cf_release_notes:
Summary: A simple error with a Project (for example, missing dependencies) can cause an unfriendly Maven error message being provided to the user, with no details of the actual error.

Cause: 
1.- Depedency fields were not mandatory
2.- Adding a non existing depedency manually produced a ugly exception to the client.

Consequence: Poor feedback to the client.

Fix: 
1.- Depedency fields are now mandatory
2.- Adding a non existing dependecy produces a friendly error in the user console, no exception is thrown to the client.

Result: Improved feedback to the user about the error.
bugs.summary: Not much friendly maven error message appears when there is some problem with project (e.g. with dependencies)

bugs.cf_release_notes:
Cause: 
The business-central creates a commit in the underlying Git repository for each new file.

Consequence: 
Creating a new project means adding new files and also filling some with content, which results in 22 commits, each without a comment.

Workaround (if any): 
None.

Result: 
The Git repository is messy. Developers working with it will have a much harder time making sense of who did what and why.
bugs.summary: Creating a project floods git with 22 uncommented commits

bugs.creator: Zuzana Krejčová
bugs.cf_release_notes:
Cause: 

Consequence: 
While a project is being created, creating a new asset in another project causes the asset to be created in the new project instead.

Workaround (if any): 
User should wait till the new project is completely created before creating another asset elsewhere. New project is complete when user can see the Project screen for the new project.

Result: 
Assets may end up in wrong location.
bugs.summary: Asset created in wrong project after creating a project

bugs.creator: Zuzana Krejčová
bugs.cf_release_notes:
Cause: 

Consequence: 
Value fields using dependent enumerations for constraints in a Guided Rule are not updated when user switches the value it depends on.

Workaround (if any): 
After switching the value depended upon, remove the last input element of the problematic constraint and re-add it.

Result: 
For an enumeration like 
  'A.a' : ['a','b','c']
  'A.b[a=b]' : ['b1','b2']
and rule containing
  'There is an A with:
     (field) a equal to (value) b
     (field) b equal to (value) b1'
if user switches value of field a to a or c (and vice-versa), the input box for value for field b is disabled instead of correctly updated. This input box then must be removed and re-added to make it work again.
bugs.summary: GRE: input for field used with dependent enumeration not updated

bugs.cf_release_notes:
Fixed Issue Summary:

While creating a rule in the GRE, if you left a constraint element on a String field incomplete, saved and reopened, the definition for the element would change and all conditional elements that were below it would disappear. That is, saving an incomplete Guided Rule Element would result in a different rule definition and parts of the rule would be missing when the rule was reopened. This has been fixed by validation that prevents the user from saving rules that do not open.

Cause: 
An incomplete constraint on a String attribute of a Data Object to a Guided Rule is not handled correctly upon saving.

Consequence: 
Leaving a constraint element on a String attribute incomplete causes the definition for this element to change and all conditions elements below it to disappear after saving and reopening the rule.

Workaround (if any): 
Do not save a Guided Rule with incomplete constraints.

Result: 
Saving an incomplete Guided Rule may result in a different rule definition and parts of the rule missing, when the rule is reopened.
bugs.summary: Guided rule editor: rule with incomplete String constraint reopens with different definition and elements missing

bugs.cf_release_notes:
Cause: Guided Rule editor is not able to recognize certain rule language features.

Consequence: When a Guided Rule file containing restrictions on the result of accumulate conditional element is opened in Guided Rule editor, these restrictions are not displayed.

Workaround (if any): Change the Guided Rule type to DRL by changing its file extension from 'rdrl' to 'drl'. The rule will open in text editor which displays the rule source correctly. The file extension renaming has to be done outside Business Central graphical UI, using GIT.

Result:
bugs.summary: Restrictions on Number that is result of 'accumulate' CE are not shown in GRE when the rule is reopened

Users without one of these roles ('analyst', 'developer') cannot see the trash icon. User with 'admin' role cannot see the icon, even though this role should grant universal access.

None.

Result: 
User with 'admin' role cannot delete log entries in Guided Decision Table Audit log, though users with role 'analyst' or 'developer' can.

bugs.cf_release_notes:
Fixed Issue Summary:

The legacy knowledge-api had an inconsistency where it did not support Commands. Trying to use Commands on this legacy API would result in UnsupportedOperationException errors. It was recommended to not use legacy API if Commands were expected to be created in a project; however, this issue has been fixed, and the exception errors no longer occur.
				

Known Issue Summary:

Due to a known issue, the legacy knowledge-api  does not support Commands. Trying to use Commands on this legacy API will result in UnsupportedOperationException errors. It is recommended that you do not use the legacy API if Commands are expected to be created in your project.

bugs.cf_release_notes:
Annotating a fact field with org.drools.definition.type.Position class in the legacy knowledge-api API does not have any effect on positional arguments in a rule.
This is because the legacy API annotations are not processed by the Drools 6 engine.
The use of annotations from within the legacy API is therefore not supported and is not backwards compatible with this release. The use of the property Reactive is also not backwards compatible and should not be used.
bugs.summary: knowledge-api: annotating a fact with org.drools.definition.type.Position not processed by the engine

An attempt to modify an event/model in the 'THEN' condition of a rule when that event had a timestamp set in the past (before pesudoclock) with an 'after' operator, resulted in a NullPointerException being thrown.

A project that tried to include a kbase by specifying it through the kmodule.xml:
<kbase name="kbase2" includes="kbase1">

bugs.cf_release_notes:
Fixed Issues Summary:

When running a stateful KieSession in STREAM mode and using events with @expires annotations, an invalid serialized session would occur in BRMS. Accordingly, when inserting an event with an @expires annotation and explicitly retracting that Event again from the engine (for example, KieSession.delete), users would receive an invalid serialized session.
				
When users later deserialized the session and immediately serialized it again, they would receive a NPE at the following location:
				org.drools.core.reteoo.ObjectTypeNode$ExpireJobContextTimerOutputMarshaller.serialize(ObjectTypeNode.java:669)

If they deserialized the session and then advanced the pseudo clock to a moment where the original event should have expired, they would receive an NPE at the following location:
				org.drools.core.common.AbstractWorkingMemory$WorkingMemoryReteExpireAction.execute(AbstractWorkingMemory.java:1524)

Therefore, when the Event was explicitly retracted with KieSession.delete(Event), it was removed from the WM but the Expiry Timer Job was not. That Expiry Timer Job was serialized with a "null" fact handle, which did not cause issues with deserialization; however, the next serialization of the session or triggering of the expire action (such as moving the pseudo clock) would trigger the issue. 
				
This issue has now been fixed for BRMS 6.0.3.
